snippet: The nation’s 1.3 million active-duty service members are in a special bind, virtually powerless to hold accountable the health care system that treats them.
abstract: Sudden death of Air Force recruit T J Moore during basic training illustrates major health care disadvantages faced by American service members; independent examination of Moore's records indicates serious lapses by military doctors, but Air Force has yet to admit any error; rules bar service members from seeking outside medical attention, and deprive them of right to challenge their care and seek answers by filing malpractice suits (Series: Military Medicine).

byline.contributor: Andrew W. Lehren contributed reporting from New York.

lead_paragraph: The nation’s 1.3 million active-duty service members are in a special bind, virtually powerless to hold accountable the health care system that treats them.

headline.print_headline: Service Members Are Left in Dark on Health Errors
headline.main: Service Members Are Left in Dark on Health Errors

keywords.name: subject
keywords.value: United States Defense and Military Forces
